name: Up to 10% OffCVG Substrate | CVG Monotub Mushroom Bulk Substrate | Coco Verm Gypsum$19.00–$540.00Price range: $19.00 through $540.00inc. GST
description: DescriptionOur pre-sterilized, ready-to-use CVG Monotub Mushroom Bulk Substrate is ideal for mushroom monotub cultivation. This substrate is hydrated to field capacity, ensuring optimal moisture content for mushroom growth. This is the most popular substrate used for monotub cultivation.Your Options:1X– 1Kg or 2Kg pre-sterilized Coco Substrate5X– 1Kg or 2Kg pre-sterilized Coco Substrate10X– 1Kg or 2Kg pre-sterilized Coco Substrate20X– 1Kg or 2Kg pre-sterilized Coco SubstrateCoco Coir + Vermiculite + Gypsum (CVG) Substrate: CVG is a popular bulk substrate that combines coco coir and vermiculite. These components offer excellent water retention with minimal nutrition. Gypsum is added for its sulfites and calcium, which supplement the mix and help keep the substrate aerated. Since mushrooms are 90% water, this substrate’s ability to absorb much water is crucial for sustaining mushrooms until the first flush. Sterilization of the substrate dramatically reduces the risk of Trichoderma contamination, a common issue for first-time growers. However, it’s important to note that contamination isn’t completely avoidable if your growing area and processes aren’t clean. Most nutrition for mushroom growth comes from grains added during inoculation, making a higher grain-to-substrate ratio beneficial for substrates like CVG. Rye is theoretically the best-suited grain for this substrate, balancing the missing nutrition, but it tends to dry out quickly and can be challenging for beginners to colonize. Millet is a more manageable alternative, offering easier handling for first-time growers. This CVG Monotub Mushroom Bulk Substrate is often called the bestMonotub Substrate.Note:Bag of coco best used asap or within 6 weeks of receiving. Longer its kept it starts to loose moisture and mushrooms are 90% waterIf you are working with our Grain spawn and do not want to use up all the spawn in one go,  inoculated a grain bag with agar or inoculated a substrate bag with grain spawn for which you had to cut open the bag but have no way to seal the bag again consider to have ourLargeSealing Bag ClipsSource and Quality of Coco CoirOur coco coir is sourced from a supplier that washes it free of salts and does not inoculate it with Trichoderma, Leading to faster colonization and fewer chances of contamination.Find  anotherMushroom Substratesin our store.

name: Pre poured MEAG Agar Plates (Antibacterial) 90mm$20.00–$35.00Price range: $20.00 through $35.00inc. GST
description: DescriptionPlease be advised that during the months of December through February, shipping agar plates can be particularly challenging due to environmental factors. When the temperature of the package exceeds 40°C, the plastic wrap or wax parafilm used for sealing may melt, shrink, or otherwise be compromised due to heat. This can increase the likelihood of contamination.A bubble or condensation on any of the plates is not a cause for concern and does not affect the product’s quality.If you encounter contamination, please send us a clear photo of the affected plates, along with the number of plates affected and your order number. A refund will be issued upon verification of the issue.Please note that we are unable to offer replacements, as the same environmental conditions may lead to similar issues. We appreciate your understanding and cooperation during this period.Pre-poured Petri dishes Malt Extract Agar (MEA) with Anti Bacterial Compounds for mushroom growing.Yourpurchase includes– 10x Parafilm pre-cut strip– 10x 90mm Petri dish with MEA with Anti Bacterial Compounds comes sealed snugly. These plates are to be stored at room temperature. Do not store them in the fridge unless colonized.Plate Shelf Life and StorageThe optimal shelf life for plates is 30-45 days. Order plates as needed, as they cannot be stored indefinitely, even in their original packaging. While most plates can last for months, their ideal shelf life is 30 days.Usage and ContaminationPlates may remain usable beyond 30 days if uncontaminated. If contamination occurs in one plate, it doesn’t affect others in the pack. Discard contaminated plates and use the rest as normal.The presence of a bubble or condensation in any of the plates is not a cause for concern.Long-term StorageExtended storage may cause plates to lose moisture, becoming stiff and papery. Use plates only if they remain gelatinous and uncontaminated. Discard any that become stiff or papery, as they can no longer support organism growth.Refund PolicyFor damaged or contaminated plates upon delivery:•⁠ ⁠Contact us within 30 days of the ORDER date•⁠ ⁠Provide photos for refund requests•⁠ ⁠No replacements are offered; only refundsStorage GuidelinesBefore inoculation:•⁠ ⁠Store in a cool, dry place (e.g., cupboard)•⁠ ⁠Avoid refrigeration to prevent condensation•⁠ ⁠Place upside down to minimize condensationAfter colonization:•⁠ ⁠Refrigerate when at least 60% colonized•⁠ ⁠Label (date and species) and put in zip-lock bags for storage•⁠ ⁠It is best to keep it in the vegetable compartment of the fridgeRemember: The packaging sleeve is not a sterile seal. Proper storage is crucial for maintaining plate quality.About the petri dishThese dishes are made of clear polystyrene, which allows for clarity while being disposable and durable. It is easy to stock and grip and has an anti-slip ring that offers stability.General MEAG informationMEAG is a gelatinous medium that is used to purify, germinate, isolate, and manipulate mushroom mycelium to reduce the chances of contamination drastically due to its antibacterial compound.These Petri dishes are 100% ready to inoculate with spores or mushroom mycelium. Its key feature is anti-bacterial compounds. In Agar mycelium cultures, antibacterial compounds have been demonstrated to inhibit bacteria to a confinable level. In several cases, spores are infected with bacteria attached to them, and they carry it to the Agar media. This will germinate fast-growing bacterial spores that make it difficult for mushroom spores to germinate (as they are slower compared to bacterial spores).On the other hand, when infected spores are introduced to MEAG, the mushroom spores will germinate and grow, leaving behind bacterial contamination. That is because the cells composing the mycelium (Hyphae) have long and sharp filaments, which carry reduced populations (if any) when they pass through the Anti Bacterial Compounds as they grow. These plates will not prevent the growth of other contaminants that are not bacteria.We recommend MEA with Anti Bacterial Compounds forGerminating spores from a spore syringe or spore print has a likelihood of contamination.Isolating a specific strain of mushroomWild mushroom cloningPurify mycelium from other contaminated agar plates or liquid cultureMalt ExtractMalt extract contains a high concentration of maltose, which provides a suitable environment for the growth of fungi. That is due to its rich source of carbon, protein, and nitrogenous compounds used as energy for fungi growth.Agar-AgarAgar-Agar is extracted from various seaweeds, such as gracilaria and gelidium (It contains no animal ingredients. Due to Agar’s unique gel property and stability, it is used as a firming and thickening agent for Petri dish experimentation.)In an unlikely situation when you receive some plates damaged or contaminated that may arise sometime from shipping, we will refund you part payment for those affected plates. Please send us the photos within one week of receiving the parcel.We offer otherPre-Poured Agar platesin our store.You can also buy theAnti-Bacterial powderfrom our store or otherpre-made Agar mixesto make your own agar plates.
clean_name: Pre poured MEAG Agar Plates (Antibacterial) 90mm

This substrate can be used with white button mushrooms but will require a pasteurizedcasing layer.Your Options:1X 2Kg pre-sterilized Manure Substrate5X 2Kg pre-sterilized Manure Substrate10X 2Kg pre-sterilized Manure SubstrateManure substrate is an advanced option typically used by experienced growers. It is not recommended for first-time growers as it is highly nutritious, making it susceptible to various types of growth. Even though the substrate is sterile, a high grain ratio (minimum 40%) is recommended to facilitate quick colonization and reduce the chances of contamination. Millet is an excellent grain choice for manure substrate due to its slightly lower nutrition and more inoculation points than rye. For instance, 1 kg of rye might have 3000 kernels, whereas millet, being smaller, might have 8000 kernels in a kg. This higher number of inoculation points in millet allows for a more even spread and faster colonization.If you are working with our Grain spawn and do not want to use up all the spawn in one go,  inoculated a grain bag with agar or inoculated a substrate bag with grain spawn for which you had to cut open the bag but have no way to seal the bag again consider to have ourLargeSealing Bag ClipsWhy Manure Substrate?Manure is highly nutritious and is often considered the gold standard amongmonotube substrates. Its rich nutritional content makes it a superb choice for mushroom cultivation.Source and Quality of ManureWe source our manure directly from a trusted farm in New South Wales. The manure, primarily horse manure and occasionally cow manure (based on availability), is aged for over a year. This aging process is critical in preparing the manure for use as a substrate, ensuring it contains the right balance of nutrients for optimal mushroom growth.Composition of the SubstrateThe ingredients of our Manure Substrate include sterilized manure, coco coir, vermiculite, and gypsum. This blend creates a balanced environment for mushrooms, providing them with the necessary nutrients and moisture retention capabilities. description: DescriptionMushroom Casing LayerThe casing layer is essential in mushroom cultivation and is predominantly used for top-fruiting varieties of mushrooms.What is a Casing Layer?A casing layer is a substrate cover designed to:Retain essential moisture.Initiate and support pinning.Prevent surface mycelium from drying out.Facilitate optimal pinset formation.Provide nutrition and trace minerals.Host microorganisms are vital for pin-set formation in some varieties.If you face challenges like side pinning or uneven pin-set on your substrate surface, our casing layer is the ideal solution. In nature, mushrooms usually form after rainfall, leveraging moist conditions and the cooling effect of moisture evaporation to induce pinning. Simulating these conditions with an apt casing layer can greatly enhance your mushroom cultivation.Types of Casing Layers:Sterilized Casing Layer: (1kg Hydrated at field capacity)Ideal for maintaining the perfect surface conditions.Best for species that prefer sterilized settings, such as top-fruiting varieties (e.g., Swordbelt, Namoeko). Some exceptions are under the pasteurized casing layer category.Reduces contamination risks in low airflow environments, like monotubs, due to its sterile nature.Our offering is ready-to-use and pre-hydrated.Pasteurized Casing Layer: (250gms dry, add 750ml boiling water to the bag directly. Creates 1 kg casing layer when hydrated.)Enriched with beneficial bacteria crucial for certain mushroom varieties.Some mushrooms need not only the ideal surface conditions but also specific bacteria for pin-set development.Designed for species like Shaggy Mane, Agaricus, and Wine Cap.Before use, add 750 boiling water to the bag and let it rest for 4-12 hours.Density of sterelised casing-Density of Casing Layer Mix:0.6 kg/L or 600 kg/m³Your Options:1X Sterilised or Pasteurised5X Sterilised or Pasteurised10X Sterilised or PasteurisedNote- When you hydrate the pasteurized casing mix, you can sterilize it if you have an autoclave and use it as a sterilized casing layer. Some species, like Almond mushrooms, may not require pasteurization or sterilization as they require the presence of heat-sensitive bacteria to fruit. For this species, add room-temperature water to the mix instead of boiling water.If you are working with our Grain spawn and do not want to use up all the spawn in one go, or inoculated a grain bag with agar, for which you had to cut open the bag but have no way to seal the bag again consider to have ourMediumSealing Bag ClipsWhich casing layer is best for me?If not growing Shaggy Mane, Agaricus, and Wine Cap, please use a sterilized casing layer.Why Choose Our Casing Layer?Proven Formula:Our casing layer blend has been refined and validated over the years.Optimal pH:Both types are adjusted to a pH of 7.5.Contamination Control:Proper airflow in your grow space is vital to ward off contamination. Our pasteurized mix uses inorganic materials and additives to minimize this risk. It also features gypsum and calcium hydroxide, enhancing nutrition and adding a pasteurizing effect. Adding a specific amount of gypsum to our mix has been proven to get rid of Trichoderma contamination drastically.Usage Guidelines:Thickness:Target a 1 cm layer.Application:Once spread, press down lightly.Timing:Only apply the casing layer after the substrate isFULLY COLONIZEDand is visibly white.Note: The enriched nutrition in our blend supports robust mushroom growth.Looking ForGrowing Mushrooms in Monotub? Check it out in our Store.If you opt against a casing layer, you can alternatively use anAtomizerto maintain substrate surface moisture(except Shaggy mane, Agaricus, and Wine cap). Ensure only small droplets form, avoiding excess water. Check regularly until the pin-set begins, then stop misting. Given the constant need for monitoring and the potential for mycelium damage, we recommend our hassle-free casing layer as the “set and forget” method.

description: DescriptionMalt Extract Yeast Agar (MYA)What is MYA?Malt Extract Agar Mix is a gelatinous medium widely used to cultivate, isolate and manipulate fungi, yeast, and moulds. It is also a method of long-term maintenance of mushroom cultures. Cerevisiae is grown on sugar beet molasses, making it a natural source of readily assimilated amino acids and proteins. For mushrooms, this means a rich supplemented diet of dietary fiber, Vitamin D, and B Complex (Thiamine, Riboflavin, Niacin, Pantothenic Acid, Folic Acid, Biotin, Vitamin B6, and Vitamin B12).*Please note that MYA is different from MEA. name: Antibacterial Powder for mushroom cultivation$25.00–$200.00Price range: $25.00 through $200.00inc. GST
description: DescriptionAntibacterial powder for Agar petri dish and mushroom growing cultivation.THIS PRODUCT IS ONLY TO BE USED FOR MYCOLOGY PURPOSES AND NOT ON HUMANS OR ANIMALS.Your purchase Includes:1gm of Antibacterial powder (Autoclavable)- Genta mycinAgar MixandPetri Dishesare not included.Visit our other listings to add items to your order.What is Antibacterial powder?This powder is an antibiotic commonly used to treat bacterial infections. In Agar mycelium cultures, it has been demonstrated to inhibit bacteria to a confinable level. It is used to purify, germinate, isolate, and manipulate mushroom mycelium, drastically reducing the chances of contamination due to its antibacterial compound. Its key feature is that it is autoclave resistant, making it easy for cultivators to use.How does this powder work?In several cases, spores are infected with bacteria attached to them, and they carry it to the Agar media. This will germinate fast-growing bacterial spores that make it difficult for mushroom spores to germinate (as they are slower compared to bacterial spores). Even when mushroom spores germinate, there is a high likelihood that the mycelium contains a bacterial infection, increasing the chances of contamination when transferring from Agar to grains, other agar plates, or liquid culture.On the other hand, when infected spores are introduced to an agar media with this antibacterial powder, the mushroom spores will germinate and grow, leaving behind bacterial contamination. That is because the cells composing the mycelium (Hyphae) have long and sharp filaments, which carry reduced populations (if any) when they pass through this antibacterial powder.Antibacterial powder Main Uses through agar plates-–  Used to purify contaminated Agar plates (through Agar transfer)–  Autoclave resistant (It is added in Agar mix prior to inoculation)–  Germinating spores from a spore syringe or spore print, which has a likelihood of contamination–  Clone wild mushroom tissue, which has a likelihood of contaminationInstructions for Making Agar mix with antibacterial powder mix Petri dishes–  Add  0.05g (1/20th of a gram)  of this antibacterial powder to your Agar mix  for every 42g of Agar Mix( MEA/MYA/PDA, etc.)–   Boil 1000ml of hot water ( for 42 gm of Agar mix)  and pour your antibacterial Agar mix in it–  Stir thoroughly with a spoon. The content needs to be poured slowly and not all at once.–  Autoclave or pressure cook for 20 minutes at 15 psi.–  Pour into Petri dishes when it reaches 50 degrees Celsius (Approximately hot enough to hold the flask/ jar with one hand), and let it set for 10 minutes. Do not stir the solution after taking it out of Autoclave, as this would trap air bubbles in this solution.–  Once petri dishes are set, inoculate them and wrap them with parafilm. Preferably, inoculate them after 3 days. This will ensure that there is no contamination in the agar plates.–  Petri dishes are best to be stored upside down to avoid condensation.We have relied on this mix to experiment at our lab using different varieties, and it has greatly reduced the amount of contamination we get by a large amount.Check out our other listings to addMycelium Cultures,Fully Colonized Agar Plates, andPre-Poured Agar plates. We also sell otherMushroom-Growing Equipment.Since we use 1/20th of a gram, this will last you a long time. It is a one-off buy for a lot of home growers. If you think you will not be using this quantity, we also offer pre mix Malt Extract Agar mix (MEA) to make agar plates and Malt Yeast Extract Agar Mix (MYA) with antibacterial powder.We offer an easy refund policy if you are unsatisfied with the product. Our highest priority is ensuring the most pleasant experience for our customers.Feel free to contact us for further information; we will be happy to help you on your mushroom journey.
clean_name: Antibacterial Powder for mushroom cultivation

description: DescriptionPlease order the Product Express post and put the product in the freezer as soon as it arrives.Expiration Standard:1 Year in the freezer from the manufacture date.Storage Conditions:it can also be stored in a fridge at 2°-6°CBenzylaminopurine (BAP) solution is a plant growth regulator commonly used in plant tissue culture applications to promote cell division and shoot proliferation.The BenefitsEasy to useInfluences plant growth and development, sets blossoms, and stimulates fruit richness by stimulating cell division.Use to supplement tissue culture media, such as MS mediaStimulates seed germination.Used for shoot development in vitro.Also, supplement Gamborg’s media and Chu’s N6 media.How To Use Benzylaminopurine (BAP) SolutionFollow the given steps to prepare the tissue culture media using PCT’s BAP solution:Prepare liquid tissue culture media using PCT’s MS, DKW media, or any other media based on your plant.Add sugar based on the quantity of media you’re making (generally, 30 grams of sugar is added for 1-litre media), 1 ml/L PPM, and 3-4 grams per litre of gellan gum or 6-8 grams per litre of agar.Then, add the desired quantity of the plant hormone.Autoclave the medium for 20 minutes at 15 psi and 121℃.Your media is ready!We offer both6-BAPpowderandsolutionforms of our plant growth regulators to meet different needs:Powder Form: This is the raw, solid form of the product. It offers a longer shelf life, is cost-effective, and is ideal for customers who prefer to prepare solutions at desired concentrations.Solution Form: This is a ready-to-use or ready-to-dilute liquid product version. name: Potato Dextrose Agar (PDA) plates Pre poured 90mm x10$40.00inc. GST
description: DescriptionPlease be advised that during the months of December through February, shipping agar plates can be particularly challenging due to environmental factors. When the temperature of the package exceeds 40°C, the plastic wrap or wax parafilm used for sealing may melt, shrink, or otherwise be compromised due to heat. This can increase the likelihood of contamination.A bubble or condensation on any of the plates is not a cause for concern and does not affect the product’s quality.If you encounter contamination, please send us a clear photo of the affected plates, along with the number of plates affected and your order number. A refund will be issued upon verification of the issue.Please note that we are unable to offer replacements, as the same environmental conditions may lead to similar issues. We appreciate your understanding and cooperation during this period.Potato dextrose agar (PDA) is a common culture medium used in microbiology laboratories for the cultivation and maintenance of fungi, particularly filamentous fungi and yeasts. It consists of mashed potatoes, dextrose (a type of sugar), and agar, which solidifies the medium to provide a solid surface for fungal growth.Some fungi perform exceptionally well on PDA medium as opposed to other mediums like MYPA.Potato dextrose is much lighter in color than other mediums, making it easier to notice contamination while keeping vigor.PDA plates are used for various purposes in microbiology, including:Isolation of fungi: PDA plates provide a nutrient-rich environment suitable for the growth of a wide range of fungi. Microbiologists can streak or spread samples onto PDA plates to isolate individual fungal colonies for further study or identification.Fungal identification: Fungi exhibit diverse morphological characteristics, such as colony color, texture, and growth pattern, which can be observed and recorded on PDA plates. These characteristics can aid in the identification of fungal species.Maintenance of fungal cultures: PDA plates can be used to maintain fungal cultures over time. Fungal strains can be stored on PDA plates at appropriate temperatures for future use or distribution to other laboratories.Study of fungal physiology and metabolism: PDA plates can be used to study various aspects of fungal physiology, including growth rate, sporulation, and response to environmental conditions or antifungal agents.Your order Includes:10 pre-poured, thick-poured PDA plates:Longer moisture retention for healthy mycelium growth.10 Parafilm pre-cut strips:Ensure a secure and sterile seal for your cultures.Durable 90mm petri dishes:Clear polystyrene for easy observation, disposable, and anti-slip for stability.Plate Shelf Life and StorageThe optimal shelf life for plates is 30-45 days. Order plates as needed, as they cannot be stored indefinitely, even in their original packaging. While most plates can last for months, their ideal shelf life is 30 days.Usage and ContaminationPlates may remain usable beyond 30 days if uncontaminated. If contamination occurs in one plate, it doesn’t affect others in the pack. Discard contaminated plates and use the rest as normal.The presence of a bubble or condensation in any of the plates is not a cause for concern.Long-term StorageExtended storage may cause plates to lose moisture, becoming stiff and papery. Use plates only if they remain gelatinous and uncontaminated. Discard any that become stiff or papery, as they can no longer support organism growth.Refund PolicyFor damaged or contaminated plates upon delivery:•⁠ ⁠Contact us within 30 days of the ORDER date•⁠ ⁠Provide photos for refund requests•⁠ ⁠No replacements are offered; only refundsStorage GuidelinesBefore inoculation:•⁠ ⁠Store in a cool, dry place (e.g., cupboard)•⁠ ⁠Avoid refrigeration to prevent condensation•⁠ ⁠Place upside down to minimize condensationAfter colonization:•⁠ ⁠Refrigerate when at least 60% colonized•⁠ ⁠Label (date and species) and put in zip-lock bags for storage•⁠ ⁠It is best to keep it in the vegetable compartment of the fridgeRemember: The packaging sleeve is not a sterile seal. Proper storage is crucial for maintaining plate quality.
clean_name: Potato Dextrose Agar (PDA) plates Pre poured 90mm x10

name: Sterile Water Agar Petri Dishes (WA) x10 with Parafilm$20.00–$35.00Price range: $20.00 through $35.00inc. GST
description: DescriptionPlease be advised that during the months of December through February, shipping agar plates can be particularly challenging due to environmental factors. When the temperature of the package exceeds 40°C, the plastic wrap or wax parafilm used for sealing may melt, shrink, or otherwise be compromised due to heat. This can increase the likelihood of contamination.A bubble or condensation on any of the plates is not a cause for concern and does not affect the product’s quality.If you encounter contamination, please send us a clear photo of the affected plates, along with the number of plates affected and your order number. A refund will be issued upon verification of the issue.Please note that we are unable to offer replacements, as the same environmental conditions may lead to similar issues. We appreciate your understanding and cooperation during this period.Pre-poured sterile Water Agar Petri Dishes (WA) Plates with parafilm also called non-nutrient agarUses- Wild mushroom and spore cloning, isolating very bad contamination cases to grow Slime mould.Pros- Mycelium grows fairly fast compared to contamination, so it is easier to isolate themCons- Very slow-mediumEach mushroom has unique genetics; capturing its best attributes is a simple but valuable skill. If you have encountered a wild mushroom or are in love with a specific strain, these dishes are your best tool. WA is an efficient medium for mushroom tissue propagation. That is due to its low nutrient value, which reduces the chances of other contaminants from thriving. On the other hand, mushroom tissues will colonize the medium under the right procedures.Moreover, this product is a powerful and simple educational tool for learning cloning techniques. We believe that cloning mushrooms is simpler than growing them. We encourage beginners to experiment with common mushrooms from the supermarket, such as the Portobello / White Button species, to learn to clone. In this way, when growing or foraging mushrooms, this skill will come in handy. We recommend using at least 5 WA plates for cloning the desired tissue. This will help purification and increase the chances of success.Your purchase includes:Your choice of quantity of 10 WA Petri dishes.10x Alcohol wipe10x Parafilm pre-cut stripsDetailed Cloning instructions (Including the best part of mushroom flesh to use for maximum success).Plate Shelf Life and StorageThe optimal shelf life for plates is 30-45 days. Order plates as needed, as they cannot be stored indefinitely, even in their original packaging. While most plates can last for months, their ideal shelf life is 30 days.Usage and ContaminationPlates may remain usable beyond 30 days if uncontaminated. If contamination occurs in one plate, it doesn’t affect others in the pack. Discard contaminated plates and use the rest as normal.The presence of a bubble or condensation in any of the plates is not a cause for concern.Long-term StorageExtended storage may cause plates to lose moisture, becoming stiff and papery. Use plates only if they remain gelatinous and uncontaminated. Discard any that become stiff or papery, as they can no longer support organism growth.Refund PolicyFor damaged or contaminated plates upon delivery:•⁠ ⁠Contact us within 30 days of the ORDER date•⁠ ⁠Provide photos for refund requests•⁠ ⁠No replacements are offered; only refundsStorage GuidelinesBefore inoculation:•⁠ ⁠Store in a cool, dry place (e.g., cupboard)•⁠ ⁠Avoid refrigeration to prevent condensation•⁠ ⁠Place upside down to minimize condensationAfter colonization:•⁠ ⁠Refrigerate when at least 60% colonized•⁠ ⁠Label (date and species) and put in zip-lock bags for storage•⁠ ⁠It is best to keep it in the vegetable compartment of the fridgeRemember: The packaging sleeve is not a sterile seal. Proper storage is crucial for maintaining plate quality.About the petri dish-These dishes are made of clear polystyrene, allowing clarity while being disposable and durable. It is easy to stock and grip and has an anti-slip ring that offers stability.Agar Plate features90mm diameter100% contamination-free due to our laboratory-grade sterile procedures.Ingredients: Agar-agar, water.Pre-sealed to avoid contaminationAgar-AgarAgar-Agar is extracted from various seaweeds, such as gracilaria and gelidium (It contains no animal ingredients. Due to Agar’s unique gel properties and stability, it is used as a firming and thickening agent for Petri dish experimentation.If you want to make your Own Water Agar petri dishes visit us onMake Agar Platesto get the ingredients and try yourself.Looking for anotherPre-Poured Agar plates, check them out in our store.

name: Pink Oyster | Pleurotus djamor | Mushroom Grow Kit- Spray and Grow – 3kg$40.00inc. GST
description: DescriptionScientific Name:Pleurotus djamorGrow only in summer or when temps are above 24°C for best resultSkill Level:EasyGrowing Time:7–14 daysShelf Life:fruiting block Cannot be stored in the fridge, fruit immediately after full colonisation, fresh fruit dont last very long, max shelf life 3-4 days.Ideal Fruiting Temp:18°C – 30°CYield:900g – 1530gSide FruitingBrand-Your kits made with Unicorn grow bags, USAUnicorn is the only bag in the world that has been tested by Eurofins, a third party lab in Europe and passed the stringent EN 1186, and USFDA 1520 for plastic migration into the substrate (Microplastic). Unicorn PP bags was tested at the highest levels of 121 C for 3.5 hours.  No PE bags or other manufacturers’ PP bags have achieved this important food safety criteria.Please note-To ensure timely delivery before Christmas, we recommend placing your order by December 5th. This allows us sufficient time for handling and shipping. To minimise the risk of delays, please select the express shipping option with Auspost.Alternatively, we suggest considering our digital gift cards, allowing the recipient to choose the kits they love from our store.Lead time (mentioned in the listing above “add to cart” button) means time it takes to prepare this order. Product in stock does not mean its ready to send out, it means it can be prepared in the lead time mentioned.About this 3kg KitComplete Kit: Everything you need is included, just spray water and follow the simple instructions.This kit uses a special Master’s Mix, a blend of sawdust, soy pellets, and water. It’s inoculated with about 300 grams of  rye or millet grain spawn to give your mushrooms the best start.We keep things simple and affordable by sending you a fresh, made-to-order bag, just like real mushroom farms use. No fancy boxes, no sitting in cold storage for weeks. This helps keep your cost down by $10; we pass that saving directly to you. We call these kits ‘almost ready to fruit’.Humidity: Keep 85–95% humidity for strong pinset formation. Mist 2–3 times daily.Light: Pink Oysters need indirect light for colour developmentAir: Ensure gentle airflow to remove CO₂Pink Oyster Mushroom Grow Kit – Grow Delicious Mushrooms In Your HomePink Oysters(Pleurotus djamor) are known for their incredibly fast colonisation and fruiting cycle, making them one of the quickest species to cultivate. Their vibrant pink hue, which is most intense in young mushrooms, fades significantly when cooked. The “bacon” or “ham” like flavour is most pronounced when they are cooked until crispy. If cooked lightly, they present a milder, woody flavour and a tender, succulent texture.The 18°C to 30°C range is their ideal fruiting temperature. The mycelium itself can often tolerate slightly higher temperatures during colonisation. This makes them exceptionally well-suited for indoor growing during summer months or in regions with consistently warm climates, where other mushroom varieties like Blue Oysters might struggle.Beyond the antioxidants mentioned, Pink Oyster mushrooms are a good source of B vitamins (like niacin and riboflavin) and minerals such as potassium and iron. They are also studied for their potential cholesterol-lowering properties due to the presence of lovastatin, a naturally occurring statin.Step-by-step Instructions & Post-Harvest CareIMPORTANT-Check the fruiting temperature when you buy a kit and ensure you can provide it with the temperature it needs.Step 1 – Let It Grow*Take the bag out of its packaging.*Stand it upright so the white filter patch is unrestricted, this is where the mycelium in the bag breathes from. Do not cut the bag for fruiting yet.*Please keep it away from direct sunlight, windows, fans, AC, or a wardrobe.Note:Full colonisation for Pink Oyster blocks can take about 2 weeks depending on  temperature ,wait until the block is white before inducing fruiting.Need to Wait?Do NOT wait to fruit a Pink oyster mushrooms, they dont do well in the fridge, fruit them straight after colonisation and eat the fruits after harvest pretty quickly too..Step 2 – Time to FruitIt’s time to move on to the fun part—fruiting!Follow these three simple steps (summarised from above):1. Cut:To prepare your side-fruiting mushroom growing kit, start by cutting a 10–12 cm “X” into the plastic on the side of the block, where the substrate touches the bag. This is where the mushrooms will fruit from. After making the cut, gently press out any trapped air inside the bag. Then, take the loose, empty upper portion of the bag (since the block only fills the lower half) and fold or roll it neatly over the top of the block. Secure it in place with tape so it doesn’t hang down or cover the fruiting area. This keeps the cut area exposed to fresh air, encouraging healthy mushroom growth from the side of the block.2. Mist:Lightly mist the cut area 2–3 times daily and keep humidity high.Stop misting when the baby mushrooms tarts to come out. Constant misting is better than heavy misting.3. Harvest:Mushrooms usually appear within 5–7 days, Twist and pull them gently at the base.More Than One Harvest?Yes! Expect 2–3 flushes. After each harvest, remove all remaining fruit bodies, allow the block to rest for 3–4 days, then soak it in cold water for 2–3 hours before resuming misting to promote new growthCommon Mistakes to avoidPink oyster mushrooms are sensitive to their surroundings, and failing to provide the right conditions is a primary source of problems.Temperature Troubles: These mushrooms thrive in warmer temperatures, typically between  18-30°C.  Temperatures that are too low can stall growth, while excessive heat can dry them out or encourage contamination.Humidity Hurdles: Maintaining high humidity, especially during the pinning and fruiting stages, is crucial. Insufficient humidity will lead to small, dry, and cracked mushroom caps. A common mistake is not misting the growing substrate frequently enough, especially in dry climates.The Air You Breathe (or Don’t): Oyster mushrooms require a good amount of fresh air exchange. A build-up of carbon dioxide in the growing environment will result in mushrooms with long, stringy stems and small caps, a clear sign of oxygen deprivation.Light Levels: While they don’t need direct sunlight, which can be harmful, complete darkness is also not ideal. Pink oyster mushrooms benefit from indirect, ambient light to develop their characteristic vibrant colour and proper cap formation.Orientation:Pink oyster will always yield more if grown as side fruiting instead of top fruiting.💡TipIf your Pink Oyster starts growing with a pink hue, great job! That means conditions are ideal. The pink colour is normal and will fade to white as the mushroom matures.What to do if pins form inside the bagDon’t worry. Just ignore the internal pins. Gently fold the top of the bag to push out excess air, cut a 10cm “X” in the side of the bag (where you want the mushrooms to grow), and begin misting that spot daily. Mushrooms will start fruiting from that cut. The internal pins will eventually be aborted naturally, as they don’t have space to grow.Checkout out our fineMisting Spray Bottleto produce tiny droplets and keep humidity high. The size of droplets formed can easily be evaporated , this constant evaporation signals mycelium to pin.Want to Learn More?This kit introduces you toStage 3:Fruiting, the final step in mushroom growing.To explore all three stages (including how mushrooms grow from spores to harvest), check out ourEducational Mushroom Growing Kit.Checkout all theMushroom Growing kits Available in Our Spray and grow 3 Kgrange.Could not fruit the bag, or was it contaminated? Send us a photo or call us, and we will help you resolve the issue.Checkout all our Spray and grow kit 3 Kg kits.

They need to sit somewhere with fresh airflow but away from direct sunlight or direct airflow while mycelium is colonizing the grains. Do not store unused jars inside the fridge. Only fully colonized jars can go inside the fridge to slow down the growth of the mycelium. Prioritize airflow over darkness.Use within 2 weeks of dispatch. The grains will last one month in shipment but it’s advisable to use them as soon as possible. Condensation in the Jar after postage is normal. Please shake the jar thoroughly to redistribute moisture.CONTAMINATION AND BREAKAGE POLICYIf you receive these jars contaminated, we can only refund you $5 per jar and cannot replace it. The jars are checked for leakage and monitored for sterilization, most of the time contamination happens due to contaminated liquid culture spore syringe or agar.If you open these jars to inoculate with agar and the jar is contaminated we cannot refund you. We recommend after receiving these jars, store them in a cool dry spot away from direct sunlight or direct airflow for up to 2 weeks(Never in the fridge) and contact us if they are contaminated during that time. Once the jars are inoculated, it’s not possible to know the source of contamination.It is best to drop a bit of spore/liquid culture in an agar plate before inoculating these jars to check if the contamination happened due to faulty jars or liquid culture.In case some Pre-sterilized grain jars arrive broken, please get in touch with us immediately or within 72 hours of delivery; after that, we cannot help you with any complaints of breakage as this is a glass product. Please carefully inspect the jars for breakage, including any cracks that may only be visible on careful inspection. We can only refund for a broken jar. We cannot replace it unless you bring the jar back to us(Sydney Residents). We will refund $20 per jar if it’s broken.TIPS1)Be ready to move to the next step once the grain jars are fully colonized. Do not leave your grains inside the jar for long; otherwise, they will harden and become a rigid rock and will be impossible to take out. If that happens, do not try to break the content of the jar by hitting with the palm of your other hand in case the jar shatters.2)When reusing the jar and lid, please do not fill your jar more than 60-70%. We need the headspace for gaseous exchange. Both jars and lids are autoclavable.3)Please do not open the jar lid, as the contents will no longer remain sterile. Only open them after full colonization.4)If your jar is contaminated, do not throw it or the lid away. Empty the contents outside in the bin or the garden and wash the jar and the lid with hot water and soap or bleach. The lid, injection port, and air filter are reusable. You can also replace them after every use if you want.5)While shaking the jar once or twice can speed up the growth, do not overdo it. It is recommended to shake once at 30% and again at 90%. Shaking at 90% is an absolute must to ensure even colonization.6)Please remember to label your jar with the species of inoculation, the date, and the type of grain, as the grain type may not be visible after full colonization unless it is broken up.7)Apart from using these Jars for grains, they can also be used tomake Liquid culture.SAFETYDo not bang the glass jar on your opposite hand to break the clumps; the glass may break and pierce your arms. Instead, heat it on a soft surface like a couch or wrapped-up towel.

name: Log Dowel Mushroom Plug Spawn | Native Australian Reishi | Ganoderma steyaertanum$20.00inc. GST
description: DescriptionCheck out all the different varieties oflog dowel plug spawnon offer.True Reishi, scientifically known as Ganoderma lucidum, is not permitted for import or sale in Australia. However, there is a native variety of Ganoderma found in Queensland, which is also considered medicinal and is the closest alternative to true Reishi. This local Ganoderma can be grown as either conks or antlers, depending on the environmental conditions. Higher CO2 levels encourage antler growth, while increased fresh air exchange leads to the formation of conks. Antlers do not produce spores, but if they are grown in a high CO2 environment and later exposed to more air, conks will form on top of the antlers and begin to release spores. Reishi mushrooms are prolific spore producers, so it’s recommended to fruit them inside bags in a high CO2 environment. Although conks are often associated with medicinal benefits, antlers also possess the same therapeutic properties. Reishi is known for its rapid colonization and is commonly used in the production of myco-materials.100pcs Log Plugs for Native Australian Reishi .Native Australian Reishi(Ganoderma steyaertanum)-Medicinal| Also known as bracket fungus | Fruiting temp: 23°-25°CSize of dowel 8*25mmWe sell the right size ofdowel inoculation drill bitin our store for these, or buy ourdowel inoculation kit.Get everything you need forGrow Mushroom on Logs. name: Liquid culture to Liquid culture expansion Kit$50.00–$150.00Price range: $50.00 through $150.00inc. GST
description: DescriptionLiquid Culture Expansion Kit InstructionsPleaseread these instructions carefullyto avoid mistakes. Making a single mistake can ruin the whole kit. Please also watch our video.About This KitWe sellglass sterilised jars, but they areonly available for pickupfrom ourMarrickville store. If you don’t live nearby, this kit is the perfect fit for you.This kit is designedfor beginnerswithno prior experience in mycology or equipment. You only need aliquid culture syringe(either purchased from us or another supplier) and aclean and still workspace.IMPORTANT:This kit is designed to expand liquid culture by a factor of 10. Do you have one syringe from a supplier?Now with this, it’s 10 syringes in about 10 days.Youcannotuse it to expand spore syringes — it ishighly discourageddue to therisk of contamination.Spore Syringe vs Liquid CultureAliquid culture (LC)syringe contains white, jellyfish-likemyceliumsuspended in nutrient liquid.Aspore syringecontainsspores, which appear as brown specks (visible or not). While expanding a spore syringe is technically possible,we strongly advise against it. Spores arenot guaranteed to be sterile, so contamination is likely to occur.Testing Your CultureYou should test your starting culture to ensure it’s clean.Addone dropof your liquid culture to theMEA cup(included in the kit) and wait at least5 days.Ifonly white myceliumgrows, your culture is clean.If any discolouration appears, it’s contaminated.What’s Included in the KitItem125 ml Jar250 ml Jar500 ml Jar1000 ml JarSterile Nutrient Liquid Culture2x 50ml4x 50ml8x 50ml16x 50mlDisposable Sterile Syringes11x 10ml21x 10ml21x 20ml41x 20mlDisposable Sterile Needles (18G)25454585Syringe Caps10202040MEA Test Cup1111Marble1111Alcohol Spray Bottle11111x Sterile jar with marble⚠️Do not open this jar!, Do not open the jar as its pre sterilised.MEA (Malt Extract Agar) test cup.We highly recommend to order 1 extra MEA cup, one to test the liquid culture from yiur supplier, and one to test the liquid culture once its expanded.Before You StartWork in aclean environmentWash your handsWearglovesand amask(recommended)Use thealcohol sprayto clean the injection port and any surfacesStep-by-Step Instructions1.Prepare the Sterile JarIMP-Do not open the jarSpray theblack injection porton the jar withalcoholandwait 30 seconds.Inject all the nutrient liquidfrom the syringe we provided into the jar through the injection black port.2.Inoculate the JarRespray the injection port with alcohol. Wait 30 seconds.Inject theentire 10ml liquid culture syringeinto the jar(That you got from us or another supplier). It may work with even 1ml, but the more starting culture, the better. 10ml is recommended as it provides a perfect expansion ratio. You can use more than 10ml, but avoid using less than 10ml.❗Do NOT mix two different syringes, even if they are the same strain.Label the jar with thestrain and the date.3.Incubate the JarLeave the jar undisturbed.After5–10 days, gentlyshake the jarto distribute the mycelium. The marble helps break up clumps.4.Test the CultureSpray the injection port with alcohol.Take anew sterile syringe and needle.Swirl the jar(don’t get the white filter wet), insert the needle through the black port, and draw1 mL of culture.If you tilt the jar to draw the liquid, ensure the white filter does not touch the liquid; if it does, it’s not a problem, but try to avoid it as much as possible.Inoculate theMEA test cupwith a few drops of the sample; do not add the entire 1 mL of liquid.Waitat least 5 days.If the plate stayswhite and clean, your expanded culture is safe. If the test did not yield clean results, there is a chance that no sterile technique was maintained or a contaminated starter culture was used. We highly recommend buying an extra Mea cup (not Meag) to test your starter liquid culture before using this kit.Dispose of theused syringe and needle safely—never reuse them.After Successful ExpansionPull liquid from the jar into new sterile syringes.Soak caps inisopropyl alcoholbefore placing them on filled syringes. Watch the video on how to do this.Label each syringe with thestrain and dateusingmasking tape(markers may rub off due to alcohol exposure).Store syringes in thefridgefor6–12 months, depending on strain.Some cultures arecold-sensitive— ask your supplier.Storage and ReuseAfter using the jar,wash it thoroughly.Keep theinjection port and air filteron the lid.Dry thoroughly andstore in a zip-lock bagin a clean, dry place. Do not store in a ziplock bag if not 100% dry.You may be able to make some more liquid culture in the microwave to reuse it.How to sterilise liquid culture in a microwave.Our plastic jar, lid, injection port, air filter, and marbles are all microwave-safe (so basically everything).Common Mistakes to Avoid❌ Reusing needles –use a new sterile needle every time❌ Skipping the test for your starting liquid culture❌ Skipping the test of your expanded culture before use❌ Using contaminated liquid culture to inoculate grain bagsTimeline SummaryOption A – Safer Route:Test your LC syringe on the MEA cup – wait5 daysIf clean, add to the jar and expand – wait10 daysTest final jar culture – wait5 daysTotal time:~20 daysOption B – Faster but Riskier Route:Skip testing, add the LC syringe directly to the jar, and wait10 daysTest final jar culture – wait5 daysTotal time:~15 daysThis Kit Does NOT Include:ExtraMEA cups– You may want to buy them to test the liquid culture you purchase.GlovesormasksGrain bagorall-in-one grow bagIf you’re anabsolute beginnerand feel unsure, we have a comprehensive instructional video available in the ‘Instructional Video’ tab. Watch us do it.Stay clean, stay safe, and happy growing!

description: DescriptionUninoculated blank dowels to make your mushroom dowels for logs.What are Dowels?Dowels are grooved wooden plugs essential for creating your mushroom dowels for logs. The preparation process involves the steps below:Boiling:First, the dowels are boiled in water. They will float and start secreting sap, which appears frothy.Moisture Absorption:The dowels will begin to sink as they absorb sufficient moisture.Sterilization:Place the dowels in breathable mushroom bags, filling up to 60% of the bag’s capacity. Seal and sterilize the bags.Inoculation:After sterilization, add grain spawn of your preferred mushroom variety to the dowels and wait for colonization.The grooves in the dowels protect the mycelium during the insertion into logs. The mycelium in the grooves will start colonizing the logs, ensuring successful mushroom growth.How to Prepare DowelsUse our specially designeddrill bitfor optimal results to create holes that fit the dowels perfectly. This ensures the dowels are snug without being too tight or too loose:If the hole is too loose,The mycelium won’t spread from the dowel to the log and may dry out.The mycelium may die due to heat and friction during insertion if the hole is too tight.Can Agar and Liquid Culture be Used for Inoculation?We do not recommend using agar or liquid culture for inoculating dowels as they either take significantly longer (up to six times more)to colonizeor fail to colonize altogether. Usegrain spawn, which we offer in 100g packs, to ensure your dowels are effectively colonized for efficient inoculation.If you need to buycolonized dowelsor a dowel inoculation kit or want to visit our shopping list created for people who want togrow mushrooms on logs, feel free to browse.

name: Plant Cell Supreme TC Grade Agar$44.00–$216.00Price range: $44.00 through $216.00inc. GST
description: DescriptionExpiration Standard:5 Years from manufacture dateStorage Conditions:Shelf stable at room temperatureSolidifying agents play a vital role in tissue culture media, providing essential support for the optimal growth and development of plants when incorporated into the medium. Additionally, the inclusion of solidifying agents helps ensure the even distribution of nutrients, hormones, and other crucial elements throughout the culture medium.The two most common solidifying agents used in the process are agar and gellan gum. Agar, derived from seaweed, is a polysaccharide. It imparts a gel-like texture to the medium, facilitating the adherence, growth, and differentiation of plant cells.Shelf stable at room TemperatureThe benefits of agar as tissue culture mediaEasy to useActs as a solid support for the growth and development of explantsAllows the absorption of nutrients by the plant cellsCost-effectiveHow To Use AgarFollow the given steps to prepare 1 liter of tissue culture media using PCT’s Supreme TC Agar:Take a beaker and add 800 ml of distilled water to it.To the water add 4.54 grams of PCT’s MS Media (or alternative medium based on your plant), 30 grams of sugar, and PPM™ (generally 1-2 ml/L).Make up the volume of the media to 1000ml.Adjust the pH of the media between 5.4-5.8.Add 6-8 grams of PCT’s Supreme Tissue Culture Grade Agar to the media and keep stirring.Autoclave the medium for 20 minutes at 15 psi and 121℃.Your media is ready!

It’s inoculated with about 300 grams of organic rye or millet grain spawn to give your mushrooms the best start.We keep things simple and affordable by sending you a fresh, made-to-order bag, just like real mushroom farms use. No fancy boxes, no sitting in cold storage for weeks. This helps keep your cost down by $10; we pass that saving directly to you. We call these kits ‘almost ready to fruit’.This kit uses the beloved Australian Reishi strain—Ganoderma steyaertanum—known for its glossy, woody Antlers/conk fruits. With proper airflow, you get classic bracket shapes; starve it of oxygen, and you’ll see striking antler formsLight: Requires indirect overhead light to give mushroom direction of growth.All  Ganoderma mushrooms are medicinal but most researched Ganoderma is Ganoderma lucidum, unfortunately its not allowed to be legally grown in Australia due to being marked as a pest.Reishi Mushroom Grow Kit – MedicinalGanoderma steyaertanumis a native Australian Reishi—celebrated for its shiny, lacquered conk fruit bodies and adaptability in myco-material applications. Depending on airflow and CO₂ levels, fruiting can take the form of glossy brackets or whimsical antlers. Harvested specimens are most often used for medicinal extracts, tinctures, and creative myco-material projects rather than culinary dishes. Reishi is generally only grown for medicinal purpose. They are grown, dried and powdered and tehn added intea and sipped in evening/night before sleep.Step-by-step Instructions & Post-Harvest CareIMPORTANT—This is an advanced fungus that needs cool, consistent humidity and excellent airflow to form proper conks rather than antlers.Step 1 – Let It Grow (3 Weeks)*Take the bag out of its packaging.*Stand it upright so the white filter patch is unrestricted, this is where the mycelium in the bag breathes from. Do not cut the bag for fruiting yet.*Please keep it away from direct sunlight, windows, fans, AC, or a wardrobe.Need to Wait?If you need to wait, store them in the fridge after full colonisation. They can take 40 days from baby mushroom to fully matured mushroom, so you can leave it to fruit if you are only going away for 1-2 weeks. The mushroom will seek air and come out of the air filter if you are not careful, if they do come out they will spore everywhere. It is advisable to cut open the bag and remove the antler for drying. This bag will fruit only once.Step 2 – Fruiting & HarvestOnce colonised and ready to fruit:1.Leave the bag upright in a indirect light with no direct airflow, avoid tubs or wardrobe even if you have door slightly open or ajar. Keep it completely upright and let mushrooms inside form for about 2 months.2. Harvest:Fruiting bodies may take a few 8 weeks to appear and mature. Harvest when the mushroom have reached the top of the bag.Don’t let the fruiting body come out of white air filter patch.Multiple Forms:Higher CO₂ levels will result in antler shapes; increased fresh air encourages traditional conks.If these mushrooms are left to fruit from side, they will directly form conks. Once a conk is formed, they will sporulate .Reishi is notorios to fruit excessively, that is why we do not let them form conks and let them just form antlers inside the bag.Common Mistakes to AvoidOpening the bag:if the bag is opened indoor they will start forming conks instead of antlers and sporulate all over your home. they can spore a lot if you are not careful.What to do if pins form inside the bagReishi bags are the easiest bags to fruit as it requires 0 maintenance. We want the pins to form inside the bag, do not open the bag and let them grow unrestricted.Always keep the bag upright.Harvest the mushrooms and sun/air dry them and keep it in a airtight container with desiccants. Ensure they are completely cracker dry. Keeping a semi moist mushroom in a contianer will lead to mould.Checkout all theMushroom Growing kits Available in Our Spray and grow 3 Kgrange.Could not fruit the bag, or was it contaminated? Send us a photo or call us, and we will help you resolve the issue.Checkout all our Spray and grow kit 3 Kg kits.

Product in stock does not mean its ready to send out, it means it can be prepared in the lead time mentioned.About this 3kg KitComplete Kit: Everything you need is included, just spray water and follow the simple instructions.This kit uses a special Master’s Mix, a blend of sawdust, soy pellets, and water. It’s inoculated with about 300 grams of  rye or millet grain spawn to give your mushrooms the best start.We keep things simple and affordable by sending you a fresh, made-to-order bag, just like real mushroom farms use. No fancy boxes, no sitting in cold storage for weeks. This helps keep your cost down by $10; we pass that saving directly to you. We call these kits ‘almost ready to fruit’.Humidity: Keep 85–95% humidity for strong pinset formation. Mist 2–3 times daily. Stop misting once the baby mushroom form.You dont spray the mushroom but spray the surface from where they will fruit.Light: Yellow Oysters need indirect light for Vibrant colour.Air: Ensure gentle airflow to remove CO₂Yellow Oyster Mushroom Grow Kit – Grow Delicious Mushrooms In Your HomeYellow Oyster Mushroom: A Golden Counterpart to the Pink VarietyThe Yellow Oyster mushroom (Pleurotus citrinopileatus), also known as the Golden Oyster, mirrors its pink relative in its rapid growth cycle and preference for warmer climates, making it a popular choice for cultivators. While sharing similarities in ease of cultivation, it boasts its own unique set of characteristics, from its vibrant appearance to its distinct flavor profile and nutritional benefits.Beyond its appealing taste and appearance, the Yellow Oyster mushroom is a nutritious food. It is a good source of B vitamins, including niacin and riboflavin, as well as minerals like potassium. Like other oyster mushrooms, it is also being explored for its potential health benefits. It contains antioxidants and compounds that may have cholesterol-lowering effects. The presence of bioactive compounds in Pleurotus species, including citrinopileatus, has led to research into their potential immunomodulatory and other medicinal properties.Step-by-step Instructions & Post-Harvest CareIMPORTANT-Check the fruiting temperature when you buy a kit and ensure you can provide it with the temperature it needs.Step 1 – Let It Grow*Take the bag out of its packaging.*Stand it upright so the white filter patch is unrestricted, this is where the mycelium in the bag breathes from. Do not cut the bag for fruiting yet.*Please keep it away from direct sunlight, windows, fans, AC, or a wardrobe.Note:Full colonisation for Yellow oyster blocks can take about 2 weeks depending on  temperature ,wait until the block is solid white before inducing fruiting.Need to Wait?If you’re not ready to start fruiting after full colonisation, you can store the bag in thefridge for up to a month .Do not store it in the fridge until the bag is fully colonised(white).Step 2 – Time to FruitAfter the 3-week waiting period, it’s time to move on to the fun part—fruiting!Follow these three simple steps (summarised from above):1. Cut:To prepare your side-fruiting mushroom growing kit, start by cutting a 10–12 cm “X” into the plastic on the side of the block, where the substrate touches the bag. This is where the mushrooms will fruit from. After making the cut, gently press out any trapped air inside the bag. Then, take the loose, empty upper portion of the bag (since the block only fills the lower half) and fold or roll it neatly over the top of the block. Secure it in place with tape so it doesn’t hang down or cover the fruiting area. This keeps the cut area exposed to fresh air, encouraging healthy mushroom growth from the side of the block.2. Mist:Lightly mist the cut area 2–3 times daily and keep humidity high.Stop misting when the baby mushrooms tarts to come out. Constant misting is better than heavy misting.3. Harvest:Mushrooms usually appear within 5–7 days and can be harvested within 1–3 weeks. Twist and pull them gently at the base.More Than One Harvest?Yes! Expect 2–3 flushes. After each harvest, remove all remaining fruit bodies, allow the block to rest for 3–4 days, then soak it in cold water for 2–3 hours before resuming misting to promote new growthCommon Mistakes to avoidOyster mushrooms are sensitive to their surroundings, and failing to provide the right conditions is a primary source of problems.Temperature Troubles: These mushrooms thrive in warmer temperatures, typically between 65-85°F (18-29°C). Temperatures that are too low can stall growth, while excessive heat can dry them out or encourage contamination.Humidity Hurdles: Maintaining high humidity, especially during the pinning and fruiting stages, is crucial. Insufficient humidity will lead to small, dry, and cracked mushroom caps. A common mistake is not misting the growing substrate frequently enough, especially in dry climates.The Air You Breathe (or Don’t): Oyster mushrooms require a good amount of fresh air exchange. A build-up of carbon dioxide in the growing environment will result in mushrooms with long, stringy stems and small caps, a clear sign of oxygen deprivation.Light Levels: While they don’t need direct sunlight, which can be harmful, complete darkness is also not ideal. Pink oyster mushrooms benefit from indirect, ambient light to develop their characteristic vibrant color and proper cap formation.What to do if pins form inside the bagDon’t worry. Just ignore the internal pins. Gently fold the top of the bag to push out excess air, cut a small “X” in the side of the bag (where you want the mushrooms to grow), and begin misting that spot daily. Mushrooms will start fruiting from that cut. The internal pins will eventually be aborted naturally, as they don’t have space to grow.Checkout out our fineMisting Spray Bottleto produce tiny droplets and keep humidity high. The size of droplets formed can easily be evaporated , this constant evaporation signals mycelium to pin.Want to Learn More?This kit introduces you toStage 3:Fruiting, the final step in mushroom growing.To explore all three stages (including how mushrooms grow from spores to harvest), check out ourEducational Mushroom Growing Kit.Checkout all theMushroom Growing kits Available in Our Spray and grow 3 Kgrange.Could not fruit the bag, or was it contaminated? Send us a photo or call us, and we will help you resolve the issue.Checkout all our Spray and grow kit 3 Kg kits.

description: DescriptionThis 10g blend is exclusively focused on treating aggressive Trichoderma presence in mushroom cultivation environments, along with other common bacterial and fungal contamination types. Product in stock does not mean its ready to send out, it means it can be prepared in the lead time mentioned.About this 3kg KitComplete Kit: Everything you need is included, just spray water and follow the simple instructions.This kit uses a special Master’s Mix, a blend of sawdust, soy pellets, and water. It’s inoculated with about 300 grams of  rye or millet grain spawn to give your mushrooms the best start.We keep things simple and affordable by sending you a fresh, made-to-order bag, just like real mushroom farms use. No fancy boxes, no sitting in cold storage for weeks. This helps keep your cost down by $10; we pass that saving directly to you. We call these kits ‘almost ready to fruit’.The Princess of Pearl –Pleurotus ostreatus(a.k.a. Princess Pearl)  is a vigorous, high-yielding commercial strain of pearl oyster. It produces dense, creamy-white clusters with a mild, buttery flavor and tender bite—ideal for sautés, pastas, and soups. It colonizes quickly and fruits well on straw or hardwood sawdust/Master’s Mix, making it beginner-friendly yet productive enough for small commercial setups.Humidity: Maintain ~85–90% RH; mist 2–3× daily to keep the cut surface moist.Light: Indirect light helps cap development; avoid direct sun.Air: Ensure gentle fresh-air exchange to prevent long stems/small caps.Princess of Pearl Oyster Grow Kit – Dense, Buttery ClustersThe Princess strain is selected for fast colonisation andresilient fruitingacross a broad band of cool-to-moderate temperatures. Princess of Pearl mushroom has the best pinset formation. Expect compact, neatly layered caps and thick stems that cook to a savory, buttery finish. For substrates, this strain performs on pasteurised straw or supplemented hardwood (Master’s Mix). Colonisation Temperature around 21–24 °C, Fruiting between 12–29 °C.Step-by-step Instructions & Post-Harvest CareIMPORTANT—Keep humidity steady and ensure gentle airflow; Princess will reward you with dense canopies and repeat flushes.Step 1 – Let It Grow*Take the bag out of its packaging.*Stand it upright so the white filter patch is unrestricted, this is where the mycelium in the bag breathes from. Do not cut the bag for fruiting yet.*Please keep it away from direct sunlight, windows, fans, AC, or a wardrobe.Note:Full colonisation for Princess of pearl oyster blocks can take about 2 weeks depending on  temperature ,wait until the block is solid white before inducing fruiting.Need to Wait?If you’re not ready to start fruiting after full colonisation, you can store the bag in thefridge for up to a month .Do not store it in the fridge until the bag is fully colonised(white).Step 2 – Fruiting & HarvestAfter full colonisation,It’s time to move on to the fun part—fruiting!1. Cut:To prepare your side-fruiting mushroom growing kit, start by cutting a 10–12 cm “X” into the plastic on the side of the block, where the substrate touches the bag. This is where the mushrooms will fruit from. After making the cut, gently press out any trapped air inside the bag. Then, take the loose, empty upper portion of the bag (since the block only fills the lower half) and fold or roll it neatly over the top of the block. Secure it in place with tape so it doesn’t hang down or cover the fruiting area. This keeps the cut area exposed to fresh air, encouraging healthy mushroom growth from the side of the block.2. Mist:Lightly mist the cut area 2–3 times daily and keep humidity high.Stop misting when the baby mushrooms tarts to come out. Constant misting is better than heavy misting.3.Harvest:Mushrooms typically appear in 7–10 days. Harvest when caps are starting to curl upwards, exposing their gills., twisting gently at the base.Flushes:Expect 2–3 flushes. After each harvest, remove all remaining fruit bodies, allow the block to rest for 3–4 days, then soak it in cold water for 2–3 hours before resuming misting to promote new growthCommon Mistakes to AvoidLow Humidity:Leads to aborted pins and cracked caps — keep the cut surface moist.High CO₂:Causes long stems and tiny caps — increase gentle airflow.Direct Sun/Heat:Dries the block and deforms caps — use indirect light.Under-supplemented Substrate:Reduces yield — Princess performs best on straw or supplemented hardwood mixes.What to do if pins form inside the bagDon’t worry. Just ignore the internal pins. Gently fold the top of the bag to push out excess air, cut a small “X” in the side of the bag (where you want the mushrooms to grow), and begin misting that spot daily. Mushrooms will start fruiting from that cut. The internal pins will eventually be aborted naturally, as they don’t have space to grow.Checkout out our fineMisting Spray Bottleto produce tiny droplets and keep humidity high. The size of droplets formed can easily be evaporated , this constant evaporation signals mycelium to pin.Want to Learn More?This kit introduces you toStage 3:Fruiting, the final step in mushroom growing.To explore all three stages (including how mushrooms grow from spores to harvest), check out ourEducational Mushroom Growing Kit.Checkout all theMushroom Growing kits Available in Our Spray and grow 3 Kgrange.Could not fruit the bag, or was it contaminated? Do not cut the bag for fruiting yet.*Please keep it away from direct sunlight, windows, fans, AC, or a wardrobe.Let it sit like this until full white (colonised)Need to Wait?If you’re not ready to start fruiting you can store the bag in thefridge for up to a month.Do not store it in the fridge until the bag is fully colonised.Step 2 – Fruiting & HarvestOnce colonised, start fruiting:1. Cut:Make a 10 cm “X” or slit on side of the bag where you want the clusters to form.2. Mist:Mist the cut area 2–3 times daily and maintain humidity above 85%. Stop misting when baby mushroom start to form.3. Harvest:Mushrooms typically appear within 7–10 days. Harvest when caps still have slightly turned-under edges by gently twisting the cluster at the base.Flushes:Expect 2–3 flushes. After each harvest, lightly soak (casing or block) for a few hours, then rest for a week before continuing.Common Mistakes to AvoidLow Humidity:Dry conditions lead to cracked caps and poor cluster formation.Poor Air Exchange:CO₂ buildup results in long stems and small caps.High Temperature:Above 20 °C slows fruiting and dulls the blue color.Strong Light:Direct sunlight can dry out the block and damage pins.💡Tip:To keep your fruit bodies compact and vibrant, maintain cool temperatures and fresh airflow—this preserves the gorgeous blue hue and firm structure.What to do if pins form inside the bagDon’t worry. Just ignore the internal pins. Gently fold the top of the bag to push out excess air, cut a small “X” in the side of the bag (where you want the mushrooms to grow), and begin misting that spot daily. Mushrooms will start fruiting from that cut. The internal pins will eventually be aborted naturally, as they don’t have space to grow.Checkout out our fineMisting Spray Bottleto produce tiny droplets and keep humidity high. description: DescriptionExpiration Standard:18 months from the manufacture dateStorage Conditions:Shelf stable at room temperatureMelting point 70-80°CGellan gum, an anionic polysaccharide, replaces agar in various clinical, bacteriological and plant tissue culture media. Its structural composition comprises a repeating tetrasaccharide unit, including two D-glucose residues, one L-rhamnose residue, and one D-glucuronic acid residue.It is an excellent alternative for nutrient media in plant tissue culture, yielding a clearer and more transparent gel than agar. Additionally, it requires only half the concentration of agar typically used in tissue culture media.The Benefits of Gellan GumEasy to useActs as a solid support for the growth and development of explantsAllows the absorption of nutrients by the plant cellsThe gel’s transparency allows one to see the development of roots or contamination from the start.Cost-effectiveSolidifying agents play a crucial role in tissue culture media by providing the necessary support to keep cells, tissues, or explants in place and ensure optimal nutrients for growth and development.How To Use Gellan GumFollow the steps below to prepare 1 litre of tissue culture media using PCT’s Gellan Gum:Take a beaker and add 800 mL of distilled water to it.To the water, add PCT’s MS Media (or alternative media) 4.54 grams, 30 grams of sugar, and PPM™ (generally 1-2 ml/L).Make up the volume of the media to 1000 mL.Adjust the pH of the media between 5.4 and 5.8.Add 3-4 g/L of PCT’s Gellan Gum to the media and keep stirring.Autoclave the medium for 20 minutes at 15 psi and 121℃.Your media is ready!This product is also available in 1Kg and 5Kg packs. name: Radical Mycology by Peter McCoy$140.00inc. GST
description: DescriptionThis comprehensive 650-page book delves into the fascinating world of mycology, covering topics such as mushroom cultivation, myco-remediation, and more. Known as the ‘Mushroom Bible,’ it is a must-have for both home cultivators and anyone intrigued by the realm of fungi. Considered one of the most accessible texts on the subject, the book provides unique and up-to-date insights into the science and art of mycology.In 2006, Peter McCoy established Radical Mycology, a grassroots organization dedicated to raising awareness about the diverse ways of working with fungi for personal, societal, and ecological well-being. A decade later, McCoy published Radical Mycology to share the wealth of knowledge and skills accumulated through the organization’s global efforts to advance the science of mycology in practical applications. Challenging prevailing notions about the importance of the Fungal Kingdom, Radical Mycology convincingly explores the multitude of reasons why fungi should be recognized, respected, and embraced for the myriad gifts they offer. As a result, this book stands as one of the most comprehensive resources on mycology, delving into the science of fungi.Interwoven with insightful essays on the lessons imparted by fungi, Radical Mycology, begins by examining the unique aspects of fungal biology, the crucial ecological roles played by micro and macro fungi, techniques for accurately identifying mushrooms and mycorrhizal fungi, the significance of lichens as indicators of environmental health, and the profound influence fungi have had on the evolution of all life forms and human cultures. Equipped with this foundational knowledge, readers are then guided in their direct interaction with fungi. The book provides in-depth guidance on making potent fungal medicines, cultivating fermenting fungi for food, and low-cost mushroom cultivation using recycled materials while achieving high-quality results akin to laboratory conditions. Going beyond the limitations of other mushroom-focused books, subsequent chapters delve into regenerative natural mushroom farming—a practice heavily influenced by permaculture design principles—along with extensive information on cultivating mycorrhizal fungi and the science of myco-remediation, which involves using fungi to mitigate pollution in our homes and environment. The book concludes with profound insights into the cultural significance of fungi, including a philosophical examination of fungal growth in the design of human societies and a thorough exploration of the history of psychoactive mushrooms.Throughout this enlightening journey, McCoy shares personal and thought-provoking perspectives based on his 15 years of practical experience and study in the field. By the end, readers are equipped with the knowledge to incorporate mycology into various aspects of their lives, communities, and environments.Featuring step-by-step protocols suitable for beginners to advanced practitioners, numerous photographs, illustrations, appendices, and profiles of 100 different species, Radical Mycology serves as an invaluable reference for individuals interested in DIY or collaborative homesteading, community organizing, food security, natural medicine, grassroots bioremediation, and the evolution of human-fungal-ecological relationships. Beyond being a mere book about mushrooms, Radical Mycology is a call to form alliances with fungi in endeavours to cultivate a healthier world. With extensive references and illustrations provided by the author, this unprecedented treatise is bound to become a classic for generations to come.Check out ourMycology Booksto learn more about this Fantastic Fungi World

However, increased fresh air exchange promotes the development of their characteristic conk-shaped fruiting bodies.True Reishi, scientifically known as Ganoderma lucidum, is not permitted for import or sale in Australia. However, there is a native variety of Ganoderma found in Queensland, which is also considered medicinal and is the closest alternative to true Reishi. This local Ganoderma can be grown as either conks or antlers, depending on the environmental conditions. Higher CO2 levels encourage antler growth, while increased fresh air exchange leads to the formation of conks. Antlers do not produce spores, but if they are grown in a high CO2 environment and later exposed to more air, conks will form on top of the antlers and begin to release spores. Reishi mushrooms are prolific spore producers, so it’s recommended to fruit them inside bags in a high CO2 environment. Although conks are often associated with medicinal benefits, antlers also possess the same therapeutic properties. Reishi is known for its rapid colonization and is commonly used in the production of myco-materials.Our agar plates are thick-poured, which helps retain moisture for longer, preventing the plates from drying and making your cultures last longer.We offerHigh-Quality Disposable GlovesandMasks, essential for maintaining sterile conditions in your mycology projects.Agar Plate features– Fully colonized Live mycelium of your choice on a 90mmMalt Yeast Peptone Agar petri dish.– Ideal for expansion into grain spawn,liquid cultures, and otherPetri dish.– High in complex food for mycelium to boost mycelium growth.Your purchase includes– 1x 90mm Petri dish with inoculumDid you know that we sell Mushroom culture in form ofLiquid culture,Log plug dowel spawn,Agar plate,Mushroom grain spawn,Sawdust Substrateand asMushroom Growing Kits?

name: Mycelium Running : How Mushrooms Can Help Save the World: Book by Paul Stamets$46.00inc. GST
description: DescriptionMycelium Running is a manual for the mycological rescue of the planet. That’s right- growing more mushrooms may be the best thing we can do to save the environment, and in this groundbreaking text from mushroom expert Paul Stamets, you’ll find out how.The basic science goes like this- Microscopic cells called “mycelium”–the fruit of which are mushrooms–recycle carbon, nitrogen, and other essential elements as they break down plant and animal debris in the creation of rich new soil. What Stamets has discovered is that we can capitalize on mycelium’s digestive power and target it to decompose toxic wastes and pollutants (mycoremediation), catch and reduce silt from streambeds and pathogens from agricultural watersheds (mycofiltration), control insect populations (mycopesticides), and generally enhance the health of our forests and gardens (mycoforestry and myco-gardening).In this comprehensive guide, you’ll find chapters detailing each of these four exciting branches of what Stamets has coined “mycorestoration,” as well as chapters on the medicinal and nutritional properties of mushrooms, inoculation methods, log and stump culture, and species selection for various environmental purposes. Heavily referenced and beautifully illustrated, this book is destined to be a classic reference for bemushroomed generations to come.Check out ourMycology Booksto learn more about this Fantastic Fungi World
